title: Authors and Citation
text: Aymeric Stamm. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stamm (2023). muscadet: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis Determinantal Point Processes. https://github.com/astamm/muscadet, https://lmjl-alea.github.io/muscadet/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {muscadet: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis of Determinantal Point Processes},   author = {Aymeric Stamm},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/astamm/muscadet, https://lmjl-alea.github.io/muscadet/}, }

what: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis of Determinantal Point Processes
title: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis of Determinantal Point Processes
text: goal muscadet provide ways simulating estimating planar point patterns according various two-mark DPP models. currently provides support Gaussian Bessel DPPs. Estimation can performed either minimizing pair correlation function contrast maximizing likelihood.

title: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis of Determinantal Point Processes
text: can install development version muscadet GitHub :

title: Multi-Mark Statistical Analysis of Determinantal Point Processes
text: typical way using muscadet studying two-mark planar DPPs use TwoMarkDPP class: one can see, model initially empty, sense parameter provided. can start setting manually one time: can notice model gets updated gives intervals feasible values parameters soon able compute information given set already known parameters. Now model fully specified can simulate point pattern via $random() method: Note computations parallelized sample size using futureverse framework. observed two-mark planar point pattern, can also use fit model automatically adjusts parameter set bounds. achieved via $fit() method: want finer control estimation methods, can use functions fit_via_pcf() fit_via_mle() outside model class.
code: library(muscadet) mod <- TwoMarkDPP$new(model = "Gauss") mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: ? #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate between marks: ? #> • Correlation between marks: ? #> • Window size: ? mod$first_intensity <- 100 mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: 100 #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: (0, 0.056) #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate between marks: ? #> • Correlation between marks: ? #> • Window size: ? mod$second_intensity <- 100 mod$first_repulsion_rate <- 0.03 mod$second_repulsion_rate <- 0.03 mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: 100 #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: 100 #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate between marks: [0.03, Inf) #> • Correlation between marks: ? #> • Window size: ? mod$cross_repulsion_rate <- 0.035 mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: 100 #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: 100 #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate between marks: 0.035 #> • Correlation between marks: [0, 0.735) #> • Window size: ? mod$between_mark_correlation <- 0.5 mod$window_size <- 1 mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: 100 #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: 100 #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: 0.03 #> • Repulsion rate between marks: 0.035 #> • Correlation between marks: 0.5 #> • Window size: 1 progressr::handlers("rstudio") withr::with_seed(1234, {   progressr::with_progress({     df <- mod$random(n = 1)   }) }) mod$fit(df[[1]]) mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: 105 #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: 102 #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: 0.034 #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: 0.037 #> • Repulsion rate between marks: 0.036 #> • Correlation between marks: 0.71 #> • Window size: 1

what: Available Parametric Determinantal Point Processes — MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS
title: Available Parametric Determinantal Point Processes — MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS
text: Lists available DPP parametric models package.

title: Available Parametric Determinantal Point Processes — MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS
Available Parametric Determinantal Point Processes — MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS
text: character vector storing available parametric DPP models.

title: Available Parametric Determinantal Point Processes — MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS

what: Two-Mark Determinantal Point Process Model — TwoMarkDPP
title: Two-Mark Determinantal Point Process Model — TwoMarkDPP
text: Implements generic two-mark planar determinantal point process model. possible set parameters, fit model observed planar point pattern simulate planar point pattern.

title: Two-Mark Determinantal Point Process Model — TwoMarkDPP
text: first_intensity Setter getter first intensity \(\rho_1\). second_intensity Setter getter second intensity \(\rho_2\). first_repulsion_rate Setter getter first repulsion rate \(\alpha_1\). second_repulsion_rate Setter getter second repulsion rate \(\alpha_2\). cross_repulsion_rate Setter getter cross repulsion rate \(\alpha_{12}\). between_mark_correlation Setter getter correlation \(\tau\) marks. window_size Setter getter window size \(L\).

title: Two-Mark Determinantal Point Process Model — TwoMarkDPP
text: TwoMarkDPP$new() TwoMarkDPP$fit() TwoMarkDPP$random() TwoMarkDPP$print() TwoMarkDPP$clone()

text: model string specifying underlying parametric model used. Choices "Gauss" "Bessel". Defaults "Gauss".

title: Two-Mark Determinantal Point Process Model — TwoMarkDPP
code: ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `TwoMarkDPP$new` ## ------------------------------------------------  mod <- TwoMarkDPP$new(model = "Gauss")  ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `TwoMarkDPP$fit` ## ------------------------------------------------  mod <- TwoMarkDPP$new(model = "Gauss") mod$fit(sim_gauss0[[1]])  ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `TwoMarkDPP$random` ## ------------------------------------------------  mod <- TwoMarkDPP$new(model = "Gauss") mod$fit(sim_gauss0[[1]]) mod$random(n = 1) #> [[1]] #> Marked planar point pattern: 197 points #> Multitype, with levels = 1, 2  #> window: rectangle = [0, 1] x [0, 1] units #>   ## ------------------------------------------------ ## Method `TwoMarkDPP$print` ## ------------------------------------------------  mod <- TwoMarkDPP$new() mod #>  #> ── Two-mark planar Gauss determinantal point process ─────────────────────────── #> • Intensity of the 1st marginal DPP: ? #> • Intensity of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate of the 1st marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate of the 2nd marginal DPP: ? #> • Repulsion rate between marks: ? #> • Correlation between marks: ? #> • Window size: ?

what: Density of determinantal point process model via direct calculation — ddetmodel.direct
title: Density of determinantal point process model via direct calculation — ddetmodel.direct
text: Evaluates density determinantal point process model given point pattern via direct calculation (.e. using FFT, etc.).

title: Density of determinantal point process model via direct calculation — ddetmodel.direct
Density of determinantal point process model via direct calculation — ddetmodel.direct
text: X object class spatstat.geom::ppp specifying planar point pattern. model object class spatstat.model::detpointprocfamilyfun specifying model used. trunc numeric value specifying model truncation preformed. Defaults 0.99. See details spatstat.model::simulate.detpointprocfamily(). log boolean value specifying whether compute logarithm. Defaults TRUE. ... Extra parameters passed next methods. Ignored.

what: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle
title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle
text: Estimation Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle
code: fit_via_mle(   X,   initial_guess = NULL,   fixed_marginal_parameters = FALSE,   model = "gauss",   optimizer = "bobyqa",   num_threads = 1,   N = 512,   verbose_level = 0 )

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle
text: X object class spatstat.geom::ppp specifying observed planar determinantal point process. initial_guess numeric vector specifying initial guess model parameters maximize likelihood. Defaults NULL, initializes \(0.5\) parameters suitable transformation \([0, 1]\). provided, expected order c(alpha1, alpha2, alpha12, tau). fixed_marginal_parameters boolean value specifying whether marginal parameters estimated separately using marginal likelihood fixed estimate cross parameters. Defaults FALSE. model string specifying DPP model. Choices "gauss" "bessel". Defaults "gauss". optimizer string specifying one available derivative-free optimizers NLOpt. Defaults "bobyqa". num_threads integer value specifying number thread run . Defaults 1L. N integer value specifying maximum truncation index Fourier transform. Defaults 512L. verbose_level integer value specifying display information optimization. Choose 0L information, 1L global information likelihood setup 2L detailed information function evaluation. Defaults `0L.

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle
text: list two components: par (optimized model parameters); value (-2 logLik maximum likelihood).

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Maximum Likelihood — fit_via_mle

what: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
text: Estimation Two-Mark Planar DPPs via Pair Correlation Function

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
code: fit_via_pcf(   X,   model = "Gauss",   rmin_alpha = 2,   rmin_alpha12 = 2,   rmin_tau = 2,   q = 1,   p = 2,   divisor_marginal = "d",   divisor_cross = "d",   method = "profiling",   B = 0L,   full_bootstrap = TRUE,   params = NULL )

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
text: X object class spatstat.geom::ppp specifying planar point pattern. model string specifying model fitted. Choices "Gauss" "Bessel". Defaults "Gauss". rmin_alpha lower bound distances taken account estimating marginal alpha parameters (default: index 2). rmin_alpha12 lower bound distances taken account estimating crossing alpha parameter (default: index 2). rmin_tau lower bound distances taken account estimating correlation (default: index 2). q Power pointwise evaluations PCF. Defaults 0.5. p Power distance empirical moodel-based PCF values. Defaults 2. divisor_marginal Choice divisor estimation formula. Choices "r" "d". See Section Empirical estimation pair correlation function details. Defaults "d". divisor_cross Choice divisor estimation formula. Choices "r" "d". See Section Empirical estimation pair correlation function details. Defaults "d". method character string specifying estimation method "profiling" "direct". Defaults "profiling". B integer value specifying number samples generated bootstrap procedure approximate distribution test statistics testing absence correlation marks. Defaults 0L perform test . full_bootstrap boolean specifying whether marginal parameters re-estimated computing bootstrapped distribution tau statistic. Defaults TRUE. params length-4 numeric vector specifying values marginal parameters known. order needs rho1, rho2, alpha1 alpha2. Defaults NULL, case, estimated.

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
text: list estimated model parameters following order: rho1, rho2, alpha1, alpha2, k12, alpha12 tau. Additional information pertaining test absence correlation marks returned list well.

what: Empirical estimation of the pair correlation function
title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf
text: empirical PCF computed kernel estimate PCF contribution interpoint distance \(d_{ij}\) estimate \(g(r)\) divided: either \(r\) using optional argument divisor = "r" functions spatstat.explore::pcf() spatstat.explore::pcfcross(); \(d_{ij}\) using optional argument divisor = "d" functions spatstat.explore::pcf() spatstat.explore::pcfcross(); intended improve bias estimator \(r\) close zero.

title: Estimation of Two-Mark Planar DPPs via the Pair Correlation Function — fit_via_pcf

what: Random generation of point patterns from a cross-type DPP — rbidpp
title: Random generation of point patterns from a cross-type DPP — rbidpp
text: Simulates one planar point patterns following given multi-mark DPP.

title: Random generation of point patterns from a cross-type DPP — rbidpp
code: rbidpp(   n = 1L,   rho1 = 100,   rho2 = 100,   alpha1 = 0.03,   alpha2 = 0.03,   alpha12 = 0.035,   tau = 0.5,   L = 1,   d = 2L,   model = MUSCADET_DPP_MODELS(),   max_trunc = 1000L )

title: Random generation of point patterns from a cross-type DPP — rbidpp
text: n integer value specifying sample size. Defaults 1L. rho1 numeric value specifying intensity 1st marginal DPP. Defaults 100L. rho2 numeric value specifying intensity 2nd marginal DPP. Defaults 100L. alpha1 numeric value specifying repulsion rate 1st DPP. Defaults 0.03. alpha2 numeric value specifying repulsion rate 2nd DPP. Defaults 0.03. alpha12 numeric value specifying repulsion rate marks. Defaults 0.05. tau numeric value specifying correlation marks. Defaults 0.2. L integer value specifying window size point pattern. Defaults 1L. d integer value specifying dimension DPP. Defaults 2L. model string specifying model used. Choices "Gauss" "Bessel". Defaults "Gauss". max_trunc integer value specifying maximum number basis functions Fourier decomposition. Defaults 1000L.

title: Random generation of point patterns from a cross-type DPP — rbidpp
text: object class spatstat.geom::ppp storing simulated point pattern.
